_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This is an executive summary of the policies, procedures and activities for compliance with the EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Requirements - Risk Management Program pursuant to Title 40 Part 68 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR 68) for Alta Fuels Pueblo facility (Alta Pueblo).



The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies are addressed in the individual RMP procedures which detail the RMP program requirements as well as how Alta Fuels complies with the applicable requirements.  Alta Pueblo is a non-responding facility for releases of the RMP-listed chemicals, so the site utilizes an Emergency Action Plan (EAP).  





Stationary Source:

The Alta Fuels (Alta) Pueblo, Colorado facility is a gasoline blending facility with approximately 430,000 gallons of capacity, blending diesel, ethanol, and blend stock gasoline. The daily average throughput is 180,000 gallons, with a maximum daily throughput of 320,000 gallons. The Pueblo facility is adding two permanent 30,000-gallon butane tanks to their operations for blending.

Regulated Substances Handled & Covered Process:

Alta Fuels Pueblo uses one chemical that is subject to reporting under this filing to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).  



The Pueblo facility includes two permanent 30,000-gallon butane tanks used to inject butane into their gasoline loading operations for blending. Each butane tank will be administratively controlled to an 85% level limit, has excess flow valves on the vapor and liquid lines and has three (3) pressure relief valves set at 250 psig. Butane is unloaded from a tankwagon into either tank and stored liquefied under pressure; the tanks are manifolded such that one can be online while the other is being filled.  Liquid butane is pumped from the online tank through loading rack meter 7 to an inline mixer where it is blended with gasoline immediately prior to loading the outbound gasoline tankwagons.



Alta Pueblo has implemented the Program

Level 3 prevention program requirements under the RMP regulations.  The required elements of the RMP prevention program are listed below:



     Employee Participation

     Process Safety Information

     Process Hazard Analysis

     Operating Procedures

     Training

     Contractors

     Pre-startup Safety Review

     Mechanical Integrity

     Hot Work Permit

     Management of Change

     Incident Investigation

     Compliance Audits



In addition, the facility meets the requirements of the RMP Emergency Planning and Response element for non-responding facilities, as detailed below. These items, their specific requirements, and how the Alta Pueblo complies with the requirements are addressed in the individual procedural documents.





The Alta Pueblo has had zero RMP reportable incidents in the previous five years.





The Alta facility has developed a written EAP that includes activation of the local emergency notification system and calling 911 from a safe location [29 CFR 1910.38(c)(1)] and directing an evacuation, including exit route assignments [29 CFR 1910.38(c)(2)]. All employees are trained to assist other employees in a safe and orderly evacuation [29 CFR 1910.38(c)(2)]. Should the scope of any incident exceed the capability of Alta staff, such as a large flammable gas release, fire, or explosion at the facility, the employee discovering emergency shall follow the protocol provided in the Emergency Action Plan to notify facility personnel, isolate the covered process if safe to do so, evacuate the facility and perform headcount at the designated muster point, and contact emergency responders. 

Emergency exit routes are through any available gate for this outdoor location and muster points for each facility are identified in the Facility Maps provided in Appendix O. In addition, designated muster points are identified by signs at each facility. Note that there are no facility processes that would require continued operation during an emergency. 



Purple K fire extinguish

ers are available at several locations within the plant site to assist with the response of small, incipient fires. Facility employees should only administer the fire extinguishers if the fire is within the capacity of the extinguisher and if the employee is trained to do so [29 CFR 1910.119(n)]. 



Alta is equipped with spill-cleanup materials for containment and cleanup of minor spills. These materials include, but are not limited to, petrochemical "soak" pads, containment booms, rags, and hay bales. For additional details on spill prevention measures, including spill response activities, refer to the facility's Spill Prevention, Control & Countermeasure Plan. 





Alta Pueblo is committed to improving our safety systems and continues to address remaining low-priority recommendations identified in the initial Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) for this covered process. Future changes will be reviewed under the Management of Change (MOC) element and will address potential changes to improve safety as part of the MOC process.
